docs.lead_paragraph: IN their State of the State messages this year, many of the nation's governors emphasized the importance of investing in the health and welfare of children, even as they proposed cutbacks in social welfare programs serving low- income families with children. This seeming contradiction symbolizes the plight of the poor in 1991. The states, ever more burdened in the decade since Ronald Reagan's "new federalism" began shifting a host of new responsibilities to them, are less able to meet those responsibilities because the recession has dried up tax revenue. The resulting cuts in state budgets often have a disproportionate effect on the poor, who depend on public welfare and public services more than other citizens.

headline.main: The Nation; A Double Dose of Pain for the Poor

docs.lead_paragraph: The mysterious admirer that Richard Bernstein describes in his About Men column "The Wrong Man" (March 3) is probably suffering from erotomania, a rare but long-recognized psychiatric condition in which a person of humble origins (usually a woman) spontaneously develops the delusion that a mutual romantic attachment exists between her and a male figure whom she sees as her superior in social, professional or financial status. Those in the public eye (politicians, celebrities, journalists) or authority figures like teachers, doctors or ministers are common objects of erotomanic delusions, which sometimes lead to harassment and, more rarely, danger for the object of the delusions. As Bernstein has found, rational arguments have no effect on these fantasies. Antipsychotic drugs often reduce the intensity of the delusion but rarely eliminate it altogether, and many patients cling for years to the one fantasy that gives meaning to what is otherwise a bleak emotional landscape.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's infant mortality rate dropped last year by the largest amount in nearly a decade, Government statistics show. The decline, which will be announced Monday, was to 9.1 deaths for 1,000 live births in 1990 from 9.7 deaths for 1,000 in 1989. The figures are in the Monthly Vital Statistics Report from the National Center for Health Statistics.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is no surprise that some restaurant, tavern and package-store owners are lobbying against a bill that would require them to post signs warning pregnant women of the dangers of alcohol consumption. But the proposal's supporters did not expect the battle to be joined by the state chapter of the National Organization for Women, which is arguing that the bill unfairly singles out women and would send a message that the rights of the fetus exceeded those of the woman carrying it.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Michigan appeals court today ruled that a women should not stand trial on charges of delivering cocaine to her newborn son through the umbilical cord in a case that civil libertarians said could set the tone for future cases involving pregnant women who abuse drugs. In a unanimous decision, the Michigan Court of Appeals rejected the state's argument that Kimberly Hardy, a 24-year-old unemployed factory worker from Muskegon, passed cocaine to her son Areanis in a way that constituted criminal delivery of drugs. The charge arose from Ms. Hardy's use of crack just hours before her son's birth.

docs.lead_paragraph: Indians can legally transport the hallucinogenic drug peyote to reservations for religious ceremonies and health purposes under an Idaho law that goes into effect on July 1. Gov. Cecil Andrus signed a bill Friday. Twenty-three states have similar laws, and Federal law already allows Indians to use the drug on reservations. Tribal leaders say peyote has medicinal and sacramental uses.
